Award.AwardTitle: Appraisal System for Superior Engineering Education Evaluation-instrument Sharing and Scholarship

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The purpose of this project is to create a web-based library of proven engineering education evaluation instruments to help build evaluation capacity for this community. The community itself is growing rapidly and there is a significant market for this resource. Many engineering educators are educational innovators, but few evaluate resulting discoveries and impacts adequately so that others might confidently adopt effective new practices. This project is focused on reversing this situation.

This resource's materials will be expert-mediated and will enable engineering educators to better document and transfer impacts of their innovations and develop additional superior evaluation instruments. This library, known as the Appraisal System for Superior Engineering Education Evaluation-instrument Sharing and Scholarship (ASSESS), expands upon proof-of-concept work led by the project investigators. The earlier work created a preliminary database and convened a national panel of 30 engineering education and evaluation professionals, who confirmed the value of a resource like ASSESS. The panel refined the design of the proposed database and recommended developing and testing an online library to:
1. test its effectiveness in enabling engineering educators to locate and use evaluation instruments to support engineering education improvement projects; and
2. support the engineering education evaluation community in the identification and refinement of evaluation instruments with potential to become major assets to the profession.
ASSESS users will be guided in instrument selection and implementation to ensure credible evaluation and interpretation of findings. Peer input will identify promising instruments and guide their development.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Appraisal System for Superior Engineering Education Evaluation-instrument Sharing and Scholarship (ASSESS) was a TUES Type 2 project funded by the National Science Foundation (NSF, DUE# 1065486), from January 15, 2011, through August 31, 2015. ASSESS built on a NSF CCLI Type 1 project (DUE# 0839898), Inventory of Evaluation Tools for Engineering Education Projects, which demonstrated the need for a repository of high quality evaluation and assessment instruments to support engineering education projects.

The overarching goal of ASSESS was to build on previous proof-of-concept work to create, thoroughly test, and strategically communicate the ASSESS web-based system, positioning it for successful adoption and implementation by the engineering education community. The project successfully: (1) enabled engineering educators to locate and effectively deploy superior evaluation instruments to enhance engineering education project discoveries and successes; and (2) supported the engineering education evaluation community in the identification and refinement of evaluation instruments with potential to become major assets to the profession. The primary outcome of the ASSESS project was a web-based tool (http://assess.tidee.org) that allows users from varying professional backgrounds and levels of assessment literacy to locate information regarding instruments used in engineering education. As of August 2015, ASSESS had information available for 201 instruments, with 35 instruments author-approved (as indicated by an asterisk in ASSESS) and others waiting to be approved.

First-year implementation included hiring a professional web programmer, conducting a needs assessment to identify potential users, selecting an adoption research design, and establishing protocols to search for and identify relevant instruments. An Engineering Work Group and a Measurement Work Group were also established to guide development of the database and web interface and to define the appraisal system for rating the quality of evaluation instruments to be entered in ASSESS. The remaining years of the project focused on: instrument identification, entry, and editing; development of the ASSESS website to support entry of and access to instrument information; and conducting adoption research by surveying and interviewing prospective ASSESS users. Adoption research focused on gathering usability data and soliciting information from various users on potential instruments to help guide website development. The adoption research study also offered a longitudinal perspective on the ASSESS development process (Brooks, Brown, Davis, & LeBeau, 2014). A team of consultants, comprised of engineering education and evaluation experts, served a valuable role in offering feedback and support throughout the project.

ASSESS creates a one-stop site where visitors can search for instruments based on instrument name, domain, technical aspects, and formatting or administration characteristics. Upon selecting an instrument, users find a summary of information regarding the instrument as well as references for uses of the instrument in engineering education, recommendations for potential use in assessment and evaluation, and a summary of reliability and validity information. In addition, the following specific instrument details are offered: general information (name, purpose, domain assessed, disciplines); publishing information (publisher, author, year published); availability (location reference); format details (number of versions, number of items, item types, assessment completion [self or other], languages); administration details (administration time; to whom instrument is administered; administration type; form choices); technical specifications (amount of validity and reliability evidence; ABET criteria addressed); references; and, instrument reviews.
